clinical_study.brief_title: Feasibility of HIV Prevention Cohort Studies Among Men Who Have Sex With Men in Sub-Saharan Africa
clinical_study.official_title: HPTN 075: Feasibility of HIV Prevention Cohort Studies Among Men Who Have Sex With Men in Sub-Saharan Africa

collaborator.agency: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID)

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to determine the feasibility of recruiting and retaining men who have sex with men (MSM) in a multi-country prospective cohort study in preparation for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) prevention studies in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA).

detailed_description.textblock: HPTN 075 is an observational cohort study. Participants will be accrued over six months at four sites in SSA using convenience sampling strategies, with no replacement for participants lost to follow-up. Each participant will be followed for 12 months, during which five study visits involving structured HIV behavioral assessments, medical examinations, and collection of biological samples will be conducted (including enrollment and quarterly follow-up visits). Participants who do not complete 12 months of follow-up will be contacted to explore reasons for no longer participating.

primary_outcome.description: all 4 sites must collectively recruit 400 participants
at least 90% of participants must be retained

secondary_outcome.description: Measured by HIV RNA from plasma samples

intervention.description: HPTN 075 is an observational study in sub-Saharan MSM

biospec_descr.textblock: Plasma samples will be stored from each study visit

study_pop.textblock: Men, regardless of HIV infection status, aged 18-44 years living in SSA who report anal sex with a man in the past 3 months.
